net.dempsy.util.executor

Class RunningEventSwitch

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.dempsy.util.executor.RunningEventSwitch

  • public class RunningEventSwitch
extends Object

    This is a helper class for coordinating a "restartable" job. A "restartable" job is one that can be started over before it's finished but there should only be on running at a time. To use it you should instantiate a RunningEventSwitch.

    When you execute a job in another thread:

    • the job should indicate it's started by calling workerRunning().
    • When the worker completes the job it should call workerFinished().
    • The worker should be checking wasPreempted() and if it ever returns 'true' the worker should exit.
    • The initiating (parent) thread should wait for the worker to start by calling waitForWorkerToStart().
    • If it subsequently needs to restart the job it should call preemptWorkerAndWait(), and then it can restart the job using a new Thread.

    The RunningEventSwitch can also monitor an externally supplied "isRunning" flag so that the job will be 'preempted' whenever that's also set to false

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      RunningEventSwitch() 
      RunningEventSwitch(AtomicBoolean externalIsRunning) 

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void preemptWorkerAndWait()
      The main thread uses this method when it needs to preempt the worker and wait for the worker to finish before continuing.
      void waitForWorkerToStart()
      This allows the main thread to wait until the worker is started in order to continue.
      boolean wasPreempted()
      The worker thread can use this method to check if it's been explicitly preempted.
      void workerFinished()
      The worker thread should indicate that it's done in a finally clause on it's way out.
      void workerRunning()
      This is called from the worker thread to notify the fact that it's been started.

        public void preemptWorkerAndWait()

      • waitForWorkerToStart

        public void waitForWorkerToStart()
        This allows the main thread to wait until the worker is started in order to continue. This method only works once. It resets the flag so a second call will block until another thread calls to workerInitiateRun().
